Expectation1: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation1: A monthly food drive for the local homeless shelter is scheduled to take place at the convent today.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: This morning, I woke early, my habit pressed and ready, heart set on the food drive. The sisters and I had planned for weeks, gathering donations and preparing meals for the shelter. As a nun, I know my place is with them, serving those in need, especially today when every pair of hands matters. But as I hurried to the convent, I remembered my civic duty—today is also Election Day. I rushed to the polling station, only to be told my registration had a mismatch. The official’s voice was firm: I must fill out a provisional ballot form, and the station closes in ten minutes. My mind raced. If I stay, I might miss the food drive, letting down my sisters and the hungry. If I leave, I neglect my responsibility as a citizen, my voice unheard. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my presence, each vital in its own way. I stood frozen, torn between the call to serve and the call to vote, my heart aching with the impossibility of being in two places at once.
